General Statement:
The NAEB is essentially a three-fold organization:
— The “trade association" of educational radio and TV stations
— The educational Radio Network; this function for TV is served by the
Educational Television and Radio Center
— The "professional association" of educational broadcasters as individuals;
this latter role is relatively new, and ve would not assert that this role
is as yet being fully performed*
As the oldest organization in the field of educational broadcasting in the
U« S. (founded in 1925) the NAEB is one of the parents of several other
organizations:
— 'Hie JCET, for which the NAEB was one of the first fund-raisers, of
which Richard B. Hull, of the NAEB, was the first Executive Director
— The ETRC, the creation of a "Network Center" having been recommended to
the FAE by the NAEB Board in 1952*
The NAEB grew essentially, in its first years, out of the few surviving
educational radio stations of the U. S., which existed in the 20*s and 30*s.
These were clustered in the midwest, with few exceptions* The NAEB*a
geographical location in Urbane is an outgrowth of this development, spreading
westward and more recently southward and eastward.
In addition to providing a rallying point, an exchange post of ideas for
educational broadcasters, ami as a thread of coBanon interests through three
decades, the NAEB has worked steadily towards education® s securing and
operating increasingly its own radio and TV facilities because of a number
of concerns. Some of these are old; some fairly recent. These include:
—» Concerns about the senses of values vhlch mass media may teach, even
though unconsciously, if used only by end for commerce.
Concerns regarding the effects of excessive spoon-feeding, and "spectatoritis"
in many areas of public life. The danger that "knowing about" things
may come to be considered a satisfactory end in the life of responsible
citizens to the detriment of "doing things about" problems, as dynamic
democracy requires.
— Concerns regarding the development of "other-directness", undue concern
with "what others will think", or "keeping up with the Joneses." Con¬
formism Is a quality which totalitarianisms spend millions to create
deliberately in their subjects. In a democracy, individualism must be
protected and nurtured.
— Concerns lest radio and TV may be overlooked as valid tools of education,
in order to make it more effective and widespread. Far this use rigid
insistence on high educational standards Erast prevail.
